intro: Sanvitalia helianthoides, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its showy, daisy-like flowers that range in color from yellow to orange. The plant typically grows as a herbaceous perennial, reaching heights of up to 2 feet, with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers bloom in the summer months, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Sanvitalia helianthoides is drought-tolerant and thrives in full sun, making it a popular choice for gardens and landscapes.
